subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Roman Alphabet
msgSnippet: In fact, in England, Medieval Scribes did use a couple more letters. I believe one was called Thorn. Check it out. Look at Icelandic Alphabet on
messageBody:
In fact, in England, Medieval Scribes did use a couple more letters. 
I believe one was called Thorn. Check it out. Look at Icelandic Alphabet
on www.omniglot.com, for something similar. But when Printing Presses
were introduced from Germany,
everyone went back to the Vanilla Roman Alphabet. Most stuff was printed in
Latin at the time, so it didn't make sense to set up an extra font for the 10%
or so of the work that was done in English.
Printing was more a craft at the beginning, much prone to Typo's and mechanical
problems, so the Printers of the time tended to
go with the flow, and not add any complexity.
And Remember, English spelling had not yet been standardized.
There were no dictionaries yet.
The Roman Alphabet matches better with the Romance Languages.
As they are all derived from Latin, the language of the Romans.
Regards, Paul V. 
P.S. I am a fan of Robert A. Heinlein too
___________________attached__________________________
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
From: Tinyallen@...
Date: Tue, 13 Nov 2007 20:49:00 -0800
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update


If the alphabet had been more phonetic from the
beginning - if the (Medieval?) scribes had wandered
away from Latin and included some of the available
vowel and consonant letters from other alphabets -
that would have helped bind the accents together a bit
better come the diaspora.

At least is seems that way to me . . .

--- Paul Tremblay <phthenry@iglou. com> wrote:

> "phonetic," but that its alphabet never was? But the
> original alphabet
> doesn't really weigh in our problem. Our problem is
> that English is
> spoken so much more variation than Spanish, so that
> even if we had
> absolutely dictatorial power to impose an alphabet
> on English speakers,
> we couldn't create something both uniform and
> natural.)

===========
Never insult anyone by accident.
- Robert A. Heinlein



Send a smile, make someone laugh, have some fun! Start now!
